text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This revision incorporates the following signiﬁcant changes:
a. IRM
– Added TE/GE IRM citations. b. IRM
– Reorganized and updated titles and department names. c. IRM

– Added the following as exempt from CIP procedures: Compliance checks part an operating units annual work plan; Strategies or work streams speciﬁcally identiﬁed in a business operation unit’s program letter; referrals of speciﬁc taxpayers received from other government agencies; TE/GE compliance work. d. IRM
– Updated and consolidated deﬁnition of Prohibited Taxpayer Contacts. Added LB&I Project Coordinator. Added Return Inventory Classiﬁcation System.
Compliance employees within all Operating Divisions.
Table of Contents
Compliance Initiative Projects
) This chapter contains procedures for the development, approval, and ment of Compliance Initiative Projects (CIPs). (
) The Tax Exempt / Government Entities (TE/GE) IRMs contain detailed tion in the following sections: • IRM
, Exempt Organizations Examination (EOE) • IRM
, Employee Plans (EP) • IRM
, Indian Tribal Government (ITG) • IRM
, Federal State Local Government (FSLG) • IRM
, Tax Exempt Bonds (TEB) (

) The purpose of this chapter is to ensure all compliance employees follow sistent guidelines and comply with Service policies regarding: • Privacy • Compliance • Security • Disclosure • Data acquisition and management • Measurement of results (

) CIPs are any activities involving contact with speciﬁc taxpayers and of taxpayer data within a group or segment, using either internal or external data to identify potential areas of non-compliance within the group or for the purpose of correcting the non-compliance. For deﬁnitions see IRM
), External Data and IRM
), Internal Data. (

) Fundamental principles of CIPs include: • Identifying trends of non-compliance and improper treatment of tax issues. • Safeguarding taxpayer privacy and protecting taxpayers against thorized disclosure of conﬁdential information or unauthorized compliance contacts. • Improving voluntary compliance. • Using data driven business decisions as the basis for expending resources. • Ensuring authorization by all functions whose resources will be cantly impacted. • Utilizing resources effectively and efficiently while treating taxpayers consistently and fairly. (
) When gathering taxpayer speciﬁc external data CIP procedures will apply gardless of whether taxpayers are contacted. (

) CIP procedures apply to all functions and units within the Internal Revenue Service and are mandatory. No deviation from these procedures is allowed without the written approval of the SB/SE Director, Exam Case Selection equivalent); LB&I Director, Compliance Planning and Analytics (CP&A); Director, Refundable Credits Policy & Program Management; or the ate TE/GE Functional Director.
Overview of Compliance Initiative Projects
The purpose of this chapter is to ensure all compliance employees follow sistent guidelines and comply with Service policies regarding:
Identifying trends of non

compliance and improper treatment of tax issues. Safeguarding taxpayer privacy and protecting taxpayers against thorized disclosure of conﬁdential information or unauthorized compliance contacts. Improving voluntary compliance. Using data driven business decisions as the basis for expending resources. Ensuring authorization by all functions whose resources will be cantly impacted. Utilizing resources effectively and efficiently while treating taxpayers consistently and fairly.

gardless of whether taxpayers are contacted. CIP procedures apply to all functions and units within the Internal Revenue Service and are mandatory. No deviation from these procedures is allowed without the written approval of the SB/SE Director, Exam Case Selection (or equivalent); LB&I Director, Compliance Planning and Analytics (CP&A); W&I Director, Refundable Credits Policy & Program Management; or the ate TE/GE Functional Director.
4.17 Compliance Initiative

CIP procedures do not apply to routine business operations. Routine business operations are structured activities commonly conducted in day-to-day opera- tions, in which taxpayers are speciﬁcally identiﬁed. Examples are:

• Contacts generated by automated return selection systems such as criminant Function(DIF), Discriminant Analysis System (DAS), or automatics (audit codes) identiﬁed during return processing. • Identiﬁcation of training returns. • Any group of taxpayers that fall within an issue, strategy or work speciﬁcally identiﬁed on a business operating unit’s annual work plan examination or compliance check. • Securing information necessary for the collection of delinquent returns and taxes. • Submitting, verifying and contacting taxpayers as a result of reports or referrals, including referrals from other government federal, state or local, as long as the referrals are not a broad market segment or treated as such. Note: Referrals should be a nominal number of speciﬁc individuals or list of individuals or businesses with potential tax implications are treated individually rather than as a group. Example: Form
, Referral Report; Form
, Information Referral; Form
-A, Information Referral; Form
, Inquiry Referral; Form
, Examination Information Form

, TE/GE Referral Information Report; referrals from other IRS functions, or referrals from other agencies. • Extending audits or investigations to related taxpayers. • Fraud/BSA compliance examinations or compliance reviews, (Refer to IRM
, Bank Secrecy Act ). • Abusive Transactions (AT) Offshore compliance examinations. • Lead Development Center (LDC) participant cases (Refer to IRM
, SB/SE Lead Development Center (SB/SE LDC) and tion Order
, Functions Related to Potential Promoters/Tax Cases). • Form

, Reports of Investigation of Transferee Liability. • Approved Research Projects which are not intended to select speciﬁc taxpayers for examination. • Projects approved through the Government Liaison Business Initiative Proposal or CSO Research Request unless compliance contacts are going to be required. Refer to IRM
, CSO Support, Disaster sistance and Issue Management Resolution System and IRM
, Stakeholder Liaison Activities. • Approved LB&I campaigns. (

) CIP procedures do not apply to Memorandums of Understanding (MOUs), if the following applicable conditions are met: a. They contain a valid business case. b. They contain clear, speciﬁc details regarding taxpayer/return selection criteria and any alternative treatments. c. They are adopted and approved at Headquarters by individuals or higher) who have authority to commit the resources of the initiating function.

Overview of Compliance Initiative Projects

They are approved by all signiﬁcantly impacted functions. The applicable executive authority such as the SB/SE Director, Exam Case Selection or equivalent; LB&I Director, Compliance Planning and Analytics (CP&A); W&I Director, Refundable Credits Policy & Program Management; or the appropriate TE/GE Functional Director are part of review and approval process.

• Taxpayer outreach/education • Revisions to forms or publications • Legislative or regulatory changes • Agreements with state or local business licensing authorities for tax compliance requirements (

) Business Case – A collection of facts developed to support a request for implementation of any compliance initiative project. The business case address all material issues, including why resources should be allocated to project for which approval is requested rather than other compliance See IRM
, Background and Objectives. (
) CIP Contact – Office/individual responsible for initiating a CIP. (
) CIP Coordinator – CIP coordinators have program responsibility for CIP projects on a Headquarters, Area, Industry or Functional level. (

) Compliance Data Environment (CDE) – CDE is a workload identiﬁcation, planning, and delivery system that operates in a web-based environment. It includes Individual, Business, and Trust returns for the current year and
years. (

) Exam Quality Technical Support (EQTS) – A program designed to the level of expertise of employees through specialization and the of audit techniques speciﬁc to particular market segments, with the goal of creasing efficiency, effectiveness, and consistency of audits within market segments. (
) External Data – Taxpayer speciﬁc data (see IRM

), Taxpayer Speciﬁc Data) collected from public and private sources outside of IRS. External data does not include non-sensitive data such as electronic asset cator and people locator services, newspaper articles, periodicals, taxpayer websites, etc. (

) Internal Data – Information that is required to be ﬁled with the IRS or is produced within the IRS or is furnished to the IRS and incorporated into its data systems. An example is information received from other government agencies as part of an agreement. (

) Monitoring – Utilize Audit Information Management System (AIMS) data as tool to track individual CIP results. National CIP Database – The National CIP Database is an Access which contains information on past and present CIPs. This database
Coordinator – CIP coordinators have program responsibility for monitoring projects on a Headquarters, Area, Industry or Functional level.
National CIP Database – The National CIP Database is an Access database which contains information on past and present CIPs. This database contains a
4.17 Compliance Initiative Projects

brief description of the activities and/or issues that each CIP addresses. The database has historical and current CIP information that is available for research by Service personnel. TE/GE will maintain its own record keeping system of CIPs. (
) Privacy – The right of taxpayers to be free from unauthorized or intrusion into their personal affairs. (
) Prohibited New Taxpayer Contacts – For the purpose of IRM
, ance Initiative Projects, any contact made with a taxpayer whose case is in status below
at the earlier of the project completion date or the date of an authorization. (
) Project Coordinator (LB&I) – LB&I office/individual responsible for initiating CIP. (
) Return Inventory Classiﬁcation System (RICS) – RICS is the workload tiﬁcation and planning system for TE/GE. (

) ROTERS (Record of Tax Enforcement Results) – data, statistics, compila- tions of information or other numerical or quantitative recordations of the tax enforcement results reached in one or more cases, but not to include the tax enforcement results of individual cases when used to determine whether an employee has exercised appropriate judgment in pursuing enforcement of tax laws based upon a review of the employee’s work on that individual (
) Security – The protection of data from loss or inappropriate use. (

) Taxpayer Speciﬁc Data – Any information that contains taxpayer identiﬁers can be traced back to a speciﬁc taxpayer. Examples are name, address, taxpayer identiﬁcation number, driver’s license number, telephone number, or coding used in place of another identiﬁer that can ultimately be traced to a speciﬁc taxpayer. (
) Taxpayer – Relates to the primary return identiﬁed under an approved CIP; does not include related returns or prior or subsequent year returns. (
) TE/GE speciﬁc glossaries are located in their respective IRMs. See IRM
, Overview.

Taxpayer Speciﬁc Data – Any information that contains taxpayer identiﬁers can be traced back to a speciﬁc taxpayer. Examples are name, address, taxpayer identiﬁcation number, driver’s license number, telephone number, or coding used in place of another identiﬁer that can ultimately be traced to a speciﬁc taxpayer. Taxpayer – Relates to the primary return identiﬁed under an approved CIP; does not include related returns or prior or subsequent year returns.
